Soil: Tolerates a variety of soils as long as adequate moisture is present
Notes: Other: brittle, weak wood but grows where other trees can't; leaves have preservative, can be used to pack fruit or root vegetables. Edible: Sap contains reasonable quantity of sugar, can be used in a drink or reduced to syrup. Seeds eaten by removing "wings" and boiling. Pollen can cause allergies.

Visuals: White to pink flowers; Evergreen, summer deciduous, summer semi-deciduous
Soil: Nearly any type except very wet. Because of its deep roots it has been used to control erosion.
Notes: Edible: Aromatic tea is made from flowers and leaves. Can be used as a hop substitute in beer. Hazard: Extended use can cause rashes or photosensitivity; contains sedative compounds.

Soil: Tolerates clay but does best in moist loamy soil
Notes: Edible:Fronds used as garnish on sweet dishes. Dried fronds used in tea. Syrup can be made from the plant. Other: This plant has been used for a variety of medical purposes, was the main ingredient in a popular cough syrup.

Soil: Tolerates sand or clay soils
Notes: Edible:Fronds used as garnish on sweet dishes. Dried fronds used in tea. Syrup can be made from the plant. Other: This plant has been used for a variety of medical purposes, was the main ingredient in a popular cough syrup.

Visuals: White to pale rose flowers; deciduous late summer through winter
Soil: Tolerates a variety of soils including clay
Notes: Hazard: All parts contain the neurotoxin aesculin. Native Americans used the nuts to stupefy fish. Saponins can be extracted and made into a soap substitute.

Soil: Best on mineral soils
Tolerant of sand and clay
Notes: Edible: Catkins can be eaten raw or cooked. Pollen may cause allergies. Hazard: Fresh inner bark is emetic.

Visuals: Red to yellow flowers; Winter deciduous
Soil: Woodland soil with organic material and good drainage
Notes: Edible: Flowers eaten raw, rich in nectar. Spring greens cooked. Hazard: Although no records of toxicity have been seen for this species, it belongs to a family that contains a number of mildly toxic species, so be sure you have a Western Columbine before consuming. Other: Native Americans used this in a wide variety of medical applications. Seeds are aromatic, can be used in sachet or crushed and rubbed on as perfume.

Visuals: Showy pink or white flowers; Evergreen
Soil: Heavy
Notes: Edible: Berries can be eaten raw or cooked. Other: Wood very hard and strong, can be used for carving or furniture. Leaves have been used as poultice for burns or as astringent.

Soil: In the wild it is most often seen growing in sand over hardpan
Notes: Best in coastal areas, does not tolerate high interior heat so if this is your area then provide afternoon shade. Edible: Flowers steeped for tea. Green mature fruits soaked in boiling water, resulting juice ok for drink or jelly. Berries/dried fruits ground into pinole.

Soil: Often gravelly, decomposed granite soil
Notes: Edible: Flowers steeped for tea. Green mature fruits soaked in boiling water, resulting juice ok for drink or jelly. Berries/dried fruits ground into pinole.

Soil: Can tolerate heavy soil but does best in well-drained soil
Notes: Edible: Fruits eaten raw or cooked. Drink made by mashing berries, covering in boiling water or soaked in sun like "sun tea". Other: A tea made from the dried leaves is strongly astringent, diuretic and an antiseptic for the urinary tract, but should be used with caution because it contains arbutin which hydrolyzes into the toxic urinary antiseptic hydroquinone. Externally, an infusion is used to treat poison oak rash.

Soil: Tolerant of clay or alluvial soil
Notes: Edible: Friuts eaten raw or cooked but are hard to digest. Berries can be crushed to make a lightly sweet drink like a cider. Other: The leaves can be boiled and the yellowish-red extract used as a cleansing body wash.

Soil: Tolerates a variety of soils but prefers sandy loam
Notes: Edible: Fruit dry and mealy, but it becomes sweeter when cooked. Added to stews etc, it is a good source of carbohydrates. The fruit can also be used to make a cooling drink or used for preserves etc.A tea is made from the dried leaves. Hazard: Large quantities can be poisonous, consumption of the plant should be avoided by pregnant women.

FloweringMonths: Apr, May, Jun, Jul, Aug, Sep, Oct
Visuals: Silvery light green to gray foliage; Evergreen
Soil: Usually found on sandy soil with low nutrient content, although it is also said to tolerate clay
Notes: Pollen may cause allergies

Soil: Tolerant of a variety of soils as long as adequate moisture is available

Visuals: Purple flowers with light-gray leaves; Summer Semi-deciduous
Soil: Tolerates sand and clay
Notes: Hazard: Although no specific reports have been seen for this species, many, if not all, members of this genus contain toxic resinoids, alkaloids and cardiac glycosides. They are usually avoided by grazing animals.Other: Rubber can be made from latex contained in the stems and leaves.

Soil: Tolerates a variety of soils including sandy, clay and saline
Notes: Hazard: Although no specific reports have been seen for this species, many, if not all, members of this genus contain toxic resinoids, alkaloids and cardiac glycosides. They are usually avoided by grazing animals.

Visuals: Fragrant eye-catching furry pale pink to pinkish-purple flowers; Winter deciduous
Soil: Tolerates clay soil but performs best with good drainage
Notes: Hazard: Although no specific reports have been seen for this species, many, if not all, members of this genus contain toxic resinoids, alkaloids and cardiac glycosides. They are usually avoided by grazing animals.Other: Rubber can be made from latex contained in the stems and leaves. Stems and leaves can be used to make paper. Seed floss is highly water resistant.

Soil: Clay, Loam, Sand, Rocky
Notes: Hazard: The fresh shoots contain thiaminase, an enzyme that robs the body of its vitamin B complex. In small quantities this enzyme will do no harm to people eating an adequate diet that is rich in vitamin B, though large quantities can cause severe health problems. The enzyme is destroyed by heat or thorough drying.

Soil: Tolerant of a variety of soils including sand, clay and alkaline
Notes: Pollen may cause allergies

FloweringMonths: Jan, Feb, Mar, Apr, May, Jun, Jul, Aug, Sep, Oct, Nov, Dec
Visuals: White flowers; Evergreen to semi-deciduous in summer
Soil: Heavier riparian soils, sandy washes
Tolerates clay but performs best in deep, rich woodland soil
Tolerates most soil types but especially good in clay
Notes: Edible: Seed can be cooked or dried and ground into powder, but is small and hard to extract.

Soil: Tolerates a variety of soils
Notes: Pollen may cause allergies

Soil: Tolerates a variety of soils
Notes: Pollen may cause allergies

Soil: Tolerates rocky, gravelly, sandy or clay soils as long as plenty of water is available
Notes: Pollen may cause allergies

Soil: Tolerant of a variety of soils as long as sufficient moisture is provided
Notes: Pollen may cause allergies

Soil: Adaptable
Notes: Pollen may cause allergies

Visuals: White, pale blue, blue, or lavender flower; Evergreen
Soil: Variable, but needs fast drainage
Notes: Edible: Tea can be made by steeping leaves in boiling water for 5 minutes. Other: Green dye can be made from leaves, red dye from roots. All parts of the plant are rich in saponins - when crushed and mixed with water they produce a good lather which is an effective and gentle soap.

Soil: Prefers slightly acidic soil but tolerates a variety of soils
Notes: Prefers sun on coast and shade inland. Edible: Flowers of most varieties can be steeped for tea, although not documented for this particular species.

Soil: Prefers beach sand
Notes: Edible: Flowers of most varieties can be steeped for tea, although not documented for this particular species.

Soil: Reported to tolerate clay and sand, but Ceanothus generally do best in well-drained soil. Do not fertilize or amend.
Notes: Edible: Flowers of most varieties can be steeped for tea, although not documented for this particular species. Other: green dye can be made from leaves. All parts of the plant are rich in saponins - when crushed and mixed with water they produce a good lather which is an effective and gentle soap.

Soil: Tolerant of sandy or clay soil
Notes: Edible: Flowers of most varieties can be steeped for tea, although not documented for this particular species. Other: green dye can be made from leaves. All parts of the plant are rich in saponins - when crushed and mixed with water they produce a good lather which is an effective and gentle soap.

Visuals: Showy purple flowers in spring; red, gold, or multicolored fall foliage; Winter deciduous
Soil: Adaptable
Notes: Requires winter frost; Edible: Flowers can be eaten raw in salads; flower buds can be pickled like capers; seedpods eaten raw, roasted or cooked.

Visuals: Green, red, or white flowers; Evergreen
Soil: Adaptable
Prefers rich, loamy soil

Visuals: Red-brown bark, white flowers; Winter deciduous
Soil: Tolerates a variety of soils but does best in moist, rich loamy soil
Notes: Hazard: Fruit can cause nausea. Other: widely employed by several native North American Indian tribes who valued it especially for its astringent and tonic bark. Decoction has been used to treat skin infections and rashes such as from poison oak.

Soil: Tolerant of a variety of garden soils as long as sufficient moisture is available
Notes: Edible: nuts used like other hazelnuts. Other: Blue dye can be made from root or inner bark. Branches used in basketry.

Soil: Tolerant of sand and clay
Tolerates a variety of soils, even clay
Tolerant of sand and clay
Notes: Edible: Seeds can be roasted and ground into a flour, but the seeds are small and hard to extract.

Soil: Tolerates a wide variety of soils
Notes: Edible: Seeds can be roasted and ground into a flour, but the seeds are small and hard to extract.

Soil: Tolerates most soils

Visuals: Red-orange flowers; Summer semi-deciduous, Winter Semi-deciduous
Soil: Tolerates clay and sand
Clay, Loam, Sand
Notes: Grows rapidly, can be invasive. Other: The stems contain 10% silica and are used for scouring metal and as a fine sandpaper. Horsetail is very astringent and makes an excellent clotting agent. Hazard: Contains equisetic acid, a potent heart and nerve sedative that is a dangerous poison when taken in high doses.

FloweringMonths: Jan, Feb, Mar, Apr, May, Jun, Jul, Aug
Soil: Clay soils on steep slopes, sandy soils on flats

Tolerates clay soil

Notes: Hazard: No records of toxicity have been seen but this species belongs to a family that contains many poisonous plants.

Notes: Edible: berries eaten raw or cooked into jam. Leaves can be used in tea.

Soil: Tolerates clay and garden soil
Notes: Edible: berries eaten raw or cooked into jam. Leaves can be used in tea.

Soil: Tolerates a variety of soils, but some subspecies have specific soil affinities
Notes: Pollen may cause allergies. Hazard: Leaves, berries and bark are poisonous

Soil: Sandy, gravelly, rocky or chalky, very well-draining soils
Notes: Other: Stem is covered in fine "hairs" that can cause skin rash on contact.

Visuals: Showy green or yellow flowers; Evergreen
Soil: Tolerates clay soil
Notes: Pollen may cause allergies. Other: Gray to black dye is obtained from berries. Wood is hard and fine-grained, has been used in cabinetry.

Soil: Tolerates clay but does best in well-drained soil

FloweringMonths: Apr, May, Jun, Jul, Aug, Sep, Oct
Soil: Adaptable
Notes: Other: The plant is used externally to treat burns, poison ivy rash, dermatitis, eczema and skin eruptions. Yellow and green dyes obtained from flowering heads and pods.

Soil: Typically sandy
Adaptable
Notes: Edible: Seeds eaten like other sunflowers. Seeds can be roasted and ground as a coffee substitute. Pollen or plant extracts may cause allergic reactions in some people. Other: The crushed leaves are used as a poultice on sores, swellings, snakebites and spider bites. Fiber from the stem is used to make paper and cloth.

Visuals: Showy white flowers, prolific red berries;  Evergreen
Soil: Tolerant of a variety of soils
Notes: Edible: Ripe berries edible. Simmer crushed berries for 30min for a cider. Can be used in fruit leather or other applications. Hazard: Fruit pits and young leaves contain cyanide. Other: Dense clusters of red berries during winter, good for wreaths and decorations. Looks like holly, and is what "Hollywood" was originally named for.

Soil: Prefers rocky substrate

Visuals: Small creamy white to pinkish flowers; Winter deciduous
Soil: Adaptable, does well in garden soil
Notes: Edible: berries edible. Other: wood is very hard and doesn't burn easily, so used for making small tools.

Soil: Tolerant of a variety of garden soils as long as sufficient moisture is available

Visuals: Lavender, red-purple, pale cream, veined purple flowers; Evergreen
Soil: Prefers heavy soils with organic matter
Notes: Hazard: Many plants in this genus are thought to be poisonous if ingested, so caution is advised. The roots are especially likely to be toxic.

Soil: Wetland plant. Tolerates a variety of soils
Notes: Other: Stems used in baskets, mats. Stems can be peeled, soaked in oil, and used as a candle. A fiber from the stems can be used to make paper.

FloweringMonths: Feb, Mar, Apr, May, Jun, Jul, Aug, Sep, Oct
Soil: Tolerates a variety of soils
Adaptable
Variable
Prefers clay or loamy soil, tolerates sandy soil
Notes: Edible: Seed can be ground into a powder and used with other ground seeds in a mush or porridge

Occurs in a variety of soils
Notes: Hazard: Seeds, leaves, and stems poisonous

Soil: Typically sandy soil
Notes: Other: A bright yellow dye is obtained from the flowers. Excellent pioneering plant: grows rapidly, providing shade for other developing plants, and adds nitrogen to soil.

Soil: Tolerates a variety of soils

Visuals: Showy cream or white flowers, prolific red or purple drupe; Evergreen
Soil: Tolerant of a variety of soils but will grow largest and fastest in coarse, fast draining, relatively fertile garden soil
Notes: Pollen may cause allergies; Edible: Fruit ok raw. Hazard:Pits are poisonous.

Visuals: Evergreen glossy dark green leaves; Evergreen
Soil: Tolerates a variety of soils but prefers a deep, well-draining loam which it usually develops over time from leaf drop
Notes: Pollen may cause allergies. Edible: Acorns edible, but the high tannin content makes them less useful than other Quercus species.

Visuals: Bronze or gold fall foliage; Winter deciduous
Soil: Prefers deep, rich soil but can utilize other soils if moisture is sufficient
Notes: Pollen may cause allergies. Edible: Acorns are edible once leached to remove tannins, after which they are ground into flour and used to make 'acorn mush' or bread.

Visuals: White to pink flowers; Winter deciduous
Soil: Many soil types
Notes: Other: May cause skin rash on contact. Leaves high in tannin, can be collected in the fall and used for brown dye; Edible: berries soaked in hot or cold water for tea, roasted fruit ground for coffee substitute.

Soil: Tolerates sandy soil
Notes: Edible: berries edible, but harvesting is challenging. Hazard: Plant is very spiny/thorny

FloweringMonths: Dec, Jan, Feb, Mar, Apr, May
Visuals: Pink to purple/white flowers; Summer deciduous
Soil: Medium and coarse, dry
Notes: Edible: berries eaten raw, cooked for jam/jelly

Visuals: White, pink, or red flowers; Winter deciduous
Soil: Tolerates a variety of soils
Notes: Edible: berries can be cooked into jam/jelly or used to make fruit leather

Visuals: Huge white flowers with yellow centers, largest flower of any CA native
Soil: Prefers sandy or gravelly soil with fast drainage
Notes: Other: Can be hard to establish, but once established, will spread aggressively. Container may be required.

Soil: Tolerates clay but does best in moist loamy soil
Notes: Edible: The berries or 'rose hips' can be eaten raw, dried or used in tea. The outer flesh is eaten, but avoid consuming the hairs within the seed cavity, which can be irritating to the mouth. All rose hips are a rich source of vitamins and minerals, especially vitamins A, C and E, flavanoids and other bio-active compounds

Soil: Tolerates a variety of soils
Notes: Edible: berries raw, cooked (e.g. jam), or dried. Tea can be made from fresh or dried leaves. Young spring shoots can be eaten raw or cooked, like asparagus.

Soil: Tolerant of a variety of soils, although performs better in well-drained soils
Notes: Edible: Substitute for typical sage in cooking

Soil: Variable

Visuals: White to pale blue or lavender flowers; Evergreen
Soil: Tolerates a variety of soils although it is happier with good drainage
Notes: Edible: The aromatic leaves can be brewed into a tea. The leaves and stems can be used as a food flavouring. The seeds can be dried then ground into a powder and used as a gruel

Visuals: Blue to lilac or purple flowers; Evergreen
Soil: Tolerates a variety of soils as long as drainage is adequate

FloweringMonths: Feb, Mar, Apr, May, Jun, Jul
Soil: Tolerates a variety of soils

Visuals: Showy cream or yellow flowers, prolific black or purple berry; Winter deciduous
Soil: Tolerates a variety of soils but prefers well-drained soils with moisture
Notes: Edible: The berries are safe and delicious once dried or cooked. Used in tea, jellies, sauces and baked goods. Hazard: Raw berries should not be eaten, or only in small quantities, because of the presence of cyanide-inducing glycosides. Other species of elderberry are less edible and should be avoided.

Soil: Adaptable to garden soils

Soil: Tolerant of sand and clay
Tolerates a variety of soils
Found in virtually every type of soil

Soil: Tolerates a variety of soils
Notes: Hazard: Berries are poisonous, although requires large quantities

Notes: Edible: leaves can be substituted for bayleaf in cooking; nuts can be roasted and eaten, or can be ground into a powder that is used with cereal flours in making bread

Prefers moist, fertile soil with good drainage
Tolerates a variety of soils as long as adequate drainage is provided. Prefers light or loamy soil.
Notes: Edible: The seed can be dried, ground into a powder and used as a thickener in soups or can be added to cereal flours when making bread. Young leaves can be eaten raw.
